title: Conan O’Brien Bids Farewell to Late Night
description: After 28 years on late-night television and 11 years on TBS, O’Brien is moving on to HBO Max.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yara Bayoumy and Jyoti Thottam
title: Opinion Q. and A.: Imran Khan Urges a New U.S.-Pakistan Bond
description: Pakistan’s prime minister on Afghanistan, India and the future of the relationship with America.
content: The U.S.-Pakistan relationship is at a watershed moment. The two countries have been locked in an uneasy embrace for the last 20 years, with the United States providing much-needed support to Pakistan in exchange for Islamabad’s assistance in the war on terror. While it hasn’t been smooth (see Pakistan’s harboring of militant groups and U.S. drone strikes that killed Pakistani civilians), the relationship has more or less endured.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Crouse
title: Nelly Korda Ties a Record, and Michelle Wie West Breaks Through
description: On a day when Korda shot a record-tying nine-under-par 63 to take the lead at the Women’s P.G.A. Championship, Wie West made her first cut at a major since 2018.
content: ATLANTA — Michelle Wie West has repeatedly expressed gratitude about returning to the L.P.G.A. Tour in 2021 after chronic wrist injuries sidelined her for the better part of two years. But that doesn’t mean she is satisfied simply teeing it up.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Jordan
title: A Tricky Tribute to the Book Review’s 125th Anniversary
description: Are you a literary trivia fiend? Put that knowledge to good use in a custom crossword puzzle.
content: For more than a century, The New York Times has been confounding and delighting our readers with word games. Some of the earliest ones — like “Two Hundred Hidden Books,” from 1903 — appeared in The New York Times Sunday Magazine, but the Book Review began dreaming up its own literary quizzes soon after that. They ran most frequently in the 1980s, when Anatole Broyard, an editor and critic at the paper, indulged his love of bookish trivia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Benner, Nick Corasaniti and Nicholas Fandos
title: Justice Dept. Sues Georgia Over Voting Restrictions Law
description: The lawsuit came after Republicans blocked ambitious federal legislation this week to protect voting rights.
content: WASHINGTON — The Justice Department sued Georgia on Friday over a sweeping voting law passed by the state’s Republican-led legislature,  the first significant move by the Biden administration to challenge state-level ballot restrictions enacted since the 2020 election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niki Kitsantonis
title: He Saved 31 People at Sea. Then Got a 142-Year Prison Sentence.
description: Greece is prosecuting migrants on charges of people smuggling, and imposing heavy jail terms. Rights groups say many migrants are being unfairly accused and sentenced.
content: ATHENS — When Hanad Abdi Mohammad grabbed the wheel of a foundering smuggling boat off the Aegean island of Lesbos last December, he said he was scared but determined to save himself and the other 33 people on board.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Christian Slater Is a Still-Life Artist
description: The former teen idol actor talks about his career comeback, being a father again and sketching his wife.
content: John Varriano, an instructor at the Art Students League, stood behind Christian Slater’s easel, studying the lines that the 51-year-old actor had sketched. “You have chops, man,” Mr. Varriano said. “You have got to keep practicing, man.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: Prosecutors Drop Rape Investigation Against French TV News Anchor
description: Several women had accused Patrick Poivre d’Arvor, a household name in France, of rape, sexual assault and harassment. But prosecutors cited a lack of evidence and an expired statute of limitations.
content: PARIS — Prosecutors in France said on Friday that they had dropped their investigation into accusations of rape, sexual assault and harassment against one of the country’s best-known television news anchors, citing a lack of evidence and an expired statute of limitations.
source.name: The New York Times

content: Clint Smith’s “How the Word Is Passed” is about how places in the United States reckon with — or fail to reckon with — their relationship to the history of slavery. On this week’s podcast, Smith says that one thing that inspired the book was his realization that “there were more homages to enslavers than to enslaved people” in New Orleans, where he grew up.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘I want to play with him,’ Gianna Floyd, George Floyd’s daughter, says in a video.
description: Mr. Floyd’s 7-year-old daughter appeared in a video played in court during Derek Chauvin’s sentencing hearing.
content: Gianna Floyd, the 7-year-old daughter of George Floyd, said in a video played in court on Friday that she missed her father and that she wished she could play with him.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On infrastructure, Biden tests the limits of having it both ways
description: President Biden’s bipartisan infrastructure agreement contains all of the contradictions and promises of the Biden brand. author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court Limits Suit on False Terrorism Ties on Credit Reports
description: In a 5-to-4 decision, the court said only people who had suffered “concrete harm” from being associated with terrorism had the right to sue.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Friday limited the scope of a class-action lawsuit against TransUnion, the credit reporting company, for errors in identifying consumers who might be on terrorism watch lists. In a 5-to-4 decision, the majority said some of the members of the class whose credit reports falsely tied them to wrongdoing had not suffered concrete injuries giving them standing to sue, notwithstanding a federal law authorizing such lawsuits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Baker
title: Air-Conditioning Was Once Taboo in Seattle. Not Anymore.
description: An intense heat wave is set to torment the Pacific Northwest. Many who have always done without air-conditioners are scrambling to get them now.
content: SEATTLE — For two decades, Becky Lichenstein embraced a custom of the Seattle area: doing without air-conditioning. With a thrifty populace living in such a temperate climate, box fans rigged to blow over ice and nighttime breezes off Puget Sound were enough to keep the peak of summer at bay.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Rauw Alejandro Draws a Fresh Blueprint for Spanish-Language Pop
description: On “Vice Versa,” the Puerto Rican singer traverses the lines of house music, baile funk, bolero and beyond, shirking convention and opening possibilities.
content: “¿Cuándo fue?,” the 10th track from Rauw Alejandro’s new album “Vice Versa,” provides an unexpected jolt. As the Puerto Rican singer mourns the departure of a lover, the producer Tainy blends rivulets of synths and delicate percussion, allowing them to bleed into a hiss of hot air. Suddenly, a skittish breakbeat drops, plunging the track into rave territory. The transition is like a static shock, the equivalent of shuffling across the floor in warm socks and touching a doorknob.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Arango
title: Derek Chauvin is sentenced to 22 and a half years for murder of George Floyd.
description: Prosecutors had sought 30 years in prison for the former police officer. Mr. Chauvin’s defense team wanted him released immediately.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The killing of George Floyd on a Minneapolis corner led to nationwide protests, a reckoning over racial injustice touching on virtually every aspect of American life and, on Friday, a substantial prison sentence — 22 and a half years — for the former police officer, Derek Chauvin, who ignored Mr. Floyd’s desperate cries for help and pressed his knee into Mr. Floyd’s neck for what seemed an eternity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melena Ryzik
title: Rita Moreno: Pathbreaker, Activist and ‘A Kick in the Pants’
description: The actress discusses being the subject of a new documentary, and spending eight-plus decades in the spotlight.
content: Rita Moreno was all of 6 when she made her professional debut, duetting with her Spanish dance instructor on a stage in Greenwich Village. “I remember every detail,” she said. She wore a traditional, resplendently ruffled dress. “We danced a jota — that was a country dance. And we played castanets. My mom let me put on lipstick — I was so thrilled.” It was 1937.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katharine Q. Seelye
title: Jacques Barzaghi, a Former Fixture Beside Jerry Brown, Dies at 82
description: Whether as policy adviser, interior decorator or barber, he was a Zen-like presence in that California politician’s orbit, and always dressed in black.
content: Jacques Barzaghi, who was a longtime confidant, alter ego and soul-mate of former Gov. Jerry Brown of California and known for his Zen sensibility and noir presence from boot to beret, died on June 1 at his home in Normandy, France. He was 82.
source.name: The New York Times

title: On the Front Line: A Night With Afghan Commandos
description: On a recent night raid, a Times photographer captured Afghanistan’s elite forces as they disrupted Taliban operations in one of the country’s most volatile provinces.
content: SOMEWHERE OVER HELMAND PROVINCE, Afghanistan — As the city lights faded and the Soviet-era military helicopter banked over the fields and canals of southern Afghanistan one night in May, the Afghan commandos on board made their final checks, looking at maps and adjusting their weapons before turning on their night-vision goggles.

description: Luma, a 27-acre complex that opens this week in southern France, blends elements like exhibition spaces, a design laboratory and a Frank Gehry-designed building on a former rail yard.
content: ARLES, France — Workers in hard hats and masks pinned tape to the beige stone walls. Wires snaked underfoot. A carpeted room holding a shallow pond and complex speaker and projection systems awaited water, sound and film.

title: 5 takeaways from Derek Chauvin’s sentencing for the murder of George Floyd.

content: PITTSFIELD, Mass. — With every other row removed, reducing its capacity to 160 from 520, the auditorium at the Barrington Stage Company’s main theater here seems about as serious as a gaptoothed 8-year-old. Forget about leg room; there’s ample space for skis and luggage.

author: By Paul Sullivan

description: When live performances stopped, artists looked for ways to take control of their music, and more investors got interested in a new type of asset.
content: Steve Jordan, a drummer, began working as a studio musician while he was still in high school in the 1970s. By age 19, he was performing with the “Saturday Night Live” band and touring with the Blues Brothers.

content: WASHINGTON — The Republican-controlled State Legislature in Arizona voted Thursday to revoke the Democratic secretary of state’s legal authority in election-related lawsuits, handing that power instead to the Republican attorney general.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Pompidou Center Gets a New Leader
description: Laurent Le Bon, a well-known figure in France’s art world, will become president of the Paris institution in July. He’ll oversee a major renovation and plans to open an outpost in New Jersey.
content: Laurent Le Bon, the president of Musée Picasso in Paris, will in July become the president of the Pompidou Center — the modern art institution, known for its inside-out architecture, that is one of France’s most popular tourist attractions.

author: By Calum Marsh
title: Wait, Who’s Fast, Who’s Furious?
description: A guide to the characters and the melodramas in the sprawling, surprisingly complicated “Fast & Furious” franchise.
content: At one point, rather a long time ago now, the “Fast & Furious” movies were about street racing. They do still involve cars moving at breakneck speeds, but only as one component in a blockbuster machine that also routinely includes high-stakes espionage, military-grade shootouts, multimillion-dollar bank heists and villainous schemes for global annihilation. They lately have more in common with James Bond or “Mission: Impossible” than with “Gone in 60 Seconds.”

title: The Murderer, the Writer, the Reckoning
